g.text: The value of Poisson’s ratio can vary in the range between
systems. However, for most of the materials that we knowfromour surrounding, its value falls in the
For anisotropic systems Poisson’s ratio changes with the direction of measurement and may
take any value between minus and plus inﬁnity [
]. A relatively recently discovered group of
materials for which Poisson’s ratio takes negative values [
the subject of intense studies, both theoretical [
to their extraordinary, counter intuitive, elastic behavior and the potential applications of these
One of the directions of research on auxetic materials is the analysis of simple atomic models
with structural-level modiﬁcations and the inﬂuence of the latter on the material’s elastic properties.
Not long ago, such nanoscale models were out of reach in the sense of preparation and, hence,
also for practical applications. However, recent development of methods for nanostructure fabrication
allows one to manufacture quasiplanar metamaterials at nanoscale, e.g., by atomic layer deposition
]. This allows one for fabrication of nanolayer [
Therefore, it is meaningful to search for such modiﬁcations at the nanoscale that lead to the decrease
It has been recently shown that a single layer of hard spheres introduced into the f.c.c. crystal of
Yukawa spheres (which in its pristine formexhibits weak auxetic properties [
-direction when the external stress is applied in the
In this work we consider only hard interactions to answer the more fundamental question: is there any,
and if so, what is the inﬂuence of the inclusion particles’ size (in relation to the size of the remaining
particles forming the matrix of the system) on Poisson’s ratio of the model system? The results of the
study are compared with the results obtained for the f.c.c. crystal composed of identical hard spheres.
The work is organized as follows: the details of the studied model are described in the next
the simulation method and the calculations of the elastic properties in the
ensemble, as well as the details concerning the parameters of simulations are presented. Section
contains the discussion of the obtained results, whereas in the last part (Section
In this work the model of
spheres (initially) forming the f.c.c. lattice is considered. In the
crystal without inclusions all the spheres have the same diameter
-th sphere. Each sphere interacts with other spheres through the
well-known hard sphere (HS) potential of the form:
is the distance between the centers of spheres
is the temperature. Into such a system we introduce an inclusion
by selecting (at close packing limit) an arbitrary crystalline plane orthogonal to
). Spheres in the plane constitute the inclusion further referred to as the nanolayer. The number
) depends only on the size of the studied system in the directions
(the latter being the numbers of the f.c.c. cells in the respective directions).
Such a system will be thought of as a unit supercell. Due to applied periodic boundary conditions,
effectively we obtain a systemwith a periodic stacking of (inﬁnite in the
-axis. The ratio of the number of spheres forming the single nanolayer to the number of all
the particles in the systemwill be referred to as the concentration
